values.description:
This pull request contains the boilerplate for the project.

* For now, it creates a shared library with almost nothing (it's not even a plugin).
* We can ran tests with `make tests`.
* We can check style with the usual `sh tools/code_check.sh`.
* We can generate doc with `make doc`.

I moved the communication report to a new `comm_report` directory.
values.title: Initial layout

This pull request contains the boilerplate for the project.

  • For now, it creates a shared library with almost nothing (it's not even a plugin).
  • We can ran tests with make tests.
  • We can check style with the usual sh tools/code_check.sh.

values.description:
First version of the communications API. These are the three main components of this pull request:

* SwarmBrokerPlugin: World plugin that centralizes all the communication sent from the agents.

* SwarmRobotPlugin: Model plugin that will be the base class from which to derive when creating a plugin to control an agent. It provides all the communication functionality to the agent plugin.

* TeamControllerPlugin: This is an example model plugin that shows how the teams would use the Swarm API.

I have included a sample world file for testing the functionality.

Compile as usual, and then run:

`gzserver ../worlds/swarm_empty.world --verbose`

I'll start working on tests on the next pull request, this is big enough.
values.title: First version of the communication API

  • TeamControllerPlugin: This is an example model plugin that shows how the teams would use the Swarm API.

values.description:
Added different vehicle types, and the ability to make them move through velocity control.

The example team plugin should make the models move.
values.title: Movement

values.description:
This pull request adds the infrastructure for managing the list of neighbors during communication:

* Allow a robot controller to request its local neighbors list using `this->Neighbors()`.
* A message is only delivered if the destination node is included among the sender's neighbors.

In the `Load()` method, the broker plugin parses the world SDF and creates a
map with information about all the members of the Swarm. In the
`Update()` function, the broker plugin updates the list of neighbors for each
member of the team. For now, this neighbors list contains all the swarm members. When
the broker plugin updates the list of neighbors of a given robot, it sends a
message to the `RobotPlugin` of that robot notifying the updated list.

The filtering of the messages happens in the `RobotPlugin` (at destination). When a message is received, the destination robot checks if its local address is included in the sender's neighbor list.

~~**Note:** This pull request is a branch of pull request #3. You can see the real diff [here](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/neighbors%0Dmovement#diff).~~ (pull request #3 was merged)
values.title: Neighbors

summary.raw:
This pull request adds the infrastructure for managing the list of neighbors during communication:

* Allow a robot controller to request its local neighbors list using `this->Neighbors()`.
* A message is only delivered if the destination node is included among the sender's neighbors.

In the `Load()` method, the broker plugin parses the world SDF and creates a
map with information about all the members of the Swarm. In the
`Update()` function, the broker plugin updates the list of neighbors for each
member of the team. For now, this neighbors list contains all the swarm members. When
the broker plugin updates the list of neighbors of a given robot, it sends a
message to the `RobotPlugin` of that robot notifying the updated list.

The filtering of the messages happens in the `RobotPlugin` (at destination). When a message is received, the destination robot checks if its local address is included in the sender's neighbor list.

~~**Note:** This pull request is a branch of pull request #3. You can see the real diff [here](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/neighbors%0Dmovement#diff).~~ (pull request #3 was merged)
summary.html:
This pull request adds the infrastructure for managing the list of neighbors during communication:

  • Allow a robot controller to request its local neighbors list using this->Neighbors().
  • A message is only delivered if the destination node is included among the sender's neighbors.

In the Load() method, the broker plugin parses the world SDF and creates a map with information about all the members of the Swarm. In the Update() function, the broker plugin updates the list of neighbors for each member of the team. For now, this neighbors list contains all the swarm members. When the broker plugin updates the list of neighbors of a given robot, it sends a message to the RobotPlugin of that robot notifying the updated list.

The filtering of the messages happens in the RobotPlugin (at destination). When a message is received, the destination robot checks if its local address is included in the sender's neighbor list.

Note: This pull request is a branch of pull request #3. You can see the real diff here. (pull request #3 was merged)

values.description:
* Add GPS sensor to each robot, with spherical coordinates set to Camp Roberts.
* In `RobotPlugin`, grab a pointer to the GPS sensor.
* Add new call, `RobotPlugin::GetPose()` to return the pose data to the user.
* Rename the `*_35*` files to `*_36*` (because they actually have 36 robots each).

*Note: this PR is built atop pull request #7, which should be merged first.  Here's a [better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branch/add_gps?dest=run_erb#diff).*
values.title: Add GPS

values.reason: I'm going to resubmit with the search area support included, because it's related to GPS.

values.description:
* Add GPS sensor to each robot, with spherical coordinates set to Camp Roberts.
* In RobotPlugin, grab a pointer to the GPS sensor.
* Add new call, RobotPlugin::Pose() to return the pose data to the user.
* Add new tag `<swarm_search_area>` to each vehicle plugin, defining relative min and max lat/long (relative to the origin as specified by `<spherical_coordinates>`).  It's a little strange to repeat this information in each vehicle plugin, but it can't go in the `<world>` without changing how SDF parsing works (it strictly follows the known element descriptions).  In any case, using `erb` to only define the string in one place works fine.
* Add new call, RobotPlugin::SearchArea() to return the region data to the user.
* Exercise the new calls in `example/TeamControllerPlugin.cc`.
* Rename the `*_35*` files to `*_36*` (because they actually have 36 robots each).

~~*Note: this PR is built atop pull request #7, which should be merged first. Here's a [better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branch/add_gps?dest=run_erb#diff).*~~

To test this change, be sure to build and install the latest `example` controller:

~~~
cd build
make
sudo make install
cd ../example/build
make
sudo make install
gzserver worlds/fixed_simple_36.world --verbose
~~~

You should see GPS and search area data from one robot, similar to:

~~~
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] lat long alt: 35.7753 -120.774 210.936
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] search area: 35.7653 35.7853 -120.784 -120.764
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] lat long alt: 35.7753 -120.774 210.946
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] search area: 35.7653 35.7853 -120.784 -120.764
~~~
values.title: Add GPS and search area

summary.raw:
* Add GPS sensor to each robot, with spherical coordinates set to Camp Roberts.
* In RobotPlugin, grab a pointer to the GPS sensor.
* Add new call, RobotPlugin::Pose() to return the pose data to the user.
* Add new tag `<swarm_search_area>` to each vehicle plugin, defining relative min and max lat/long (relative to the origin as specified by `<spherical_coordinates>`).  It's a little strange to repeat this information in each vehicle plugin, but it can't go in the `<world>` without changing how SDF parsing works (it strictly follows the known element descriptions).  In any case, using `erb` to only define the string in one place works fine.
* Add new call, RobotPlugin::SearchArea() to return the region data to the user.
* Exercise the new calls in `example/TeamControllerPlugin.cc`.
* Rename the `*_35*` files to `*_36*` (because they actually have 36 robots each).

~~*Note: this PR is built atop pull request #7, which should be merged first. Here's a [better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branch/add_gps?dest=run_erb#diff).*~~

To test this change, be sure to build and install the latest `example` controller:

~~~
cd build
make
sudo make install
cd ../example/build
make
sudo make install
gzserver worlds/fixed_simple_36.world --verbose
~~~

You should see GPS and search area data from one robot, similar to:

~~~
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] lat long alt: 35.7753 -120.774 210.936
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] search area: 35.7653 35.7853 -120.784 -120.764
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] lat long alt: 35.7753 -120.774 210.946
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] search area: 35.7653 35.7853 -120.784 -120.764
~~~
summary.html:
• Add GPS sensor to each robot, with spherical coordinates set to Camp Roberts.
  • In RobotPlugin, grab a pointer to the GPS sensor.
  • Add new call, RobotPlugin::Pose() to return the pose data to the user.
  • Add new tag <swarm_search_area> to each vehicle plugin, defining relative min and max lat/long (relative to the origin as specified by <spherical_coordinates>). It's a little strange to repeat this information in each vehicle plugin, but it can't go in the <world> without changing how SDF parsing works (it strictly follows the known element descriptions). In any case, using erb to only define the string in one place works fine.
  • Add new call, RobotPlugin::SearchArea() to return the region data to the user.
  • Exercise the new calls in example/TeamControllerPlugin.cc.
  • Rename the *_35* files to *_36* (because they actually have 36 robots each).

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #7, which should be merged first. Here's a better diff.

To test this change, be sure to build and install the latest example controller:

cd build
make
sudo make install
cd ../example/build
make
sudo make install
gzserver worlds/fixed_simple_36.world --verbose

You should see GPS and search area data from one robot, similar to:

[Msg] [192.168.2.1] lat long alt: 35.7753 -120.774 210.936
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] search area: 35.7653 35.7853 -120.784 -120.764
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] lat long alt: 35.7753 -120.774 210.946
[Msg] [192.168.2.1] search area: 35.7653 35.7853 -120.784 -120.764

values.description:
We can now use terrains. Currently on the `ground_simple_2.world` has been updated to use terrain.

Ground vehicles are clamped to the ground. There is a difference between the terrain height computed by OGRE and ODE. This results in models occasionally passing through the terrain.
values.title: Add terrain

summary.raw:
We can now use terrains. Currently on the `ground_simple_2.world` has been updated to use terrain.

Ground vehicles are clamped to the ground. There is a difference between the terrain height computed by OGRE and ODE. This results in models occasionally passing through the terrain.
summary.html:
We can now use terrains. Currently on the ground_simple_2.world has been updated to use terrain.

Ground vehicles are clamped to the ground. There is a difference between the terrain height computed by OGRE and ODE. This results in models occasionally passing through the terrain.

values.description:
* Add an IMU sensor to each robot that returns linear velocity, angular velocity and orientation with respect a reference position (initial position). I've used a combination of an IMU sensor and reading the linear velocity directly from the model.
* Add a compass sensor to each robot that returns the bearing with respect the true North. Gazebo angles work in the range of `PI`, `-PI` but a typical compass seems to work in `0`, `2*PI`. I've used the yaw angle of the robot, translated and normalized it.
* Worlds updated with the new `<imu>` sensors for each model.
* `example/TeamControllerPlugin.cc` updated for using the new `Imu()` and `Bearing()` calls.

You can try any of the world files and check the console output to make sure that the IMU/bearing values make sense.

[Here's the tutorial](#!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial_6-IMU_bearing_sensor) (need pull request #14).

**Note:** Using my laptop and launching Gazebo with any of the `*_36.world` was causing Gazebo to freeze. I believe is due to the massive number of `std::cout`s in the `TeamControllerPlugin::OnDataReceived` callback. Maybe we should comment this code to prevent hangs when we have a large team and lots of communication.
values.title: Imu and compass sensors

summary.raw:
* Add an IMU sensor to each robot that returns linear velocity, angular velocity and orientation with respect a reference position (initial position). I've used a combination of an IMU sensor and reading the linear velocity directly from the model.
* Add a compass sensor to each robot that returns the bearing with respect the true North. Gazebo angles work in the range of `PI`, `-PI` but a typical compass seems to work in `0`, `2*PI`. I've used the yaw angle of the robot, translated and normalized it.
* Worlds updated with the new `<imu>` sensors for each model.
* `example/TeamControllerPlugin.cc` updated for using the new `Imu()` and `Bearing()` calls.

You can try any of the world files and check the console output to make sure that the IMU/bearing values make sense.

[Here's the tutorial](#!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial_6-IMU_bearing_sensor) (need pull request #14).

**Note:** Using my laptop and launching Gazebo with any of the `*_36.world` was causing Gazebo to freeze. I believe is due to the massive number of `std::cout`s in the `TeamControllerPlugin::OnDataReceived` callback. Maybe we should comment this code to prevent hangs when we have a large team and lots of communication.
summary.html:
• Add an IMU sensor to each robot that returns linear velocity, angular velocity and orientation with respect a reference position (initial position). I've used a combination of an IMU sensor and reading the linear velocity directly from the model.
  • Add a compass sensor to each robot that returns the bearing with respect the true North. Gazebo angles work in the range of PI, -PI but a typical compass seems to work in 0, 2*PI. I've used the yaw angle of the robot, translated and normalized it.
  • Worlds updated with the new <imu> sensors for each model.
  • example/TeamControllerPlugin.cc updated for using the new Imu() and Bearing() calls.

You can try any of the world files and check the console output to make sure that the IMU/bearing values make sense.

Here's the tutorial (need pull request #14).

Note: Using my laptop and launching Gazebo with any of the *_36.world was causing Gazebo to freeze. I believe is due to the massive number of std::couts in the TeamControllerPlugin::OnDataReceived callback. Maybe we should comment this code to prevent hangs when we have a large team and lots of communication.

values.description:
PR originally started by @gerkey.

First steps toward a communication model in the broker:

* Model to decide when a vehicle is a neighbor.

* Model to decide when a vehicle can communicate with a neighbor.

* Model to decide when a vehicle goes into a communication outage.

* Ability to load the model parameters via SDF.

I'll include a second part with the ray tracing to detect line of sight between the vehicles.

We don't have any tests yet, so to check it you have to play with the model parameters and the console/log output.
values.title: Communication model - part1

summary.raw:
PR originally started by @gerkey.

First steps toward a communication model in the broker:

* Model to decide when a vehicle is a neighbor.

* Model to decide when a vehicle can communicate with a neighbor.

* Model to decide when a vehicle goes into a communication outage.

* Ability to load the model parameters via SDF.

I'll include a second part with the ray tracing to detect line of sight between the vehicles.

We don't have any tests yet, so to check it you have to play with the model parameters and the console/log output.
summary.html:
PR originally started by @gerkey.

First steps toward a communication model in the broker:

  • Model to decide when a vehicle is a neighbor.

  • Model to decide when a vehicle can communicate with a neighbor.

  • Model to decide when a vehicle goes into a communication outage.

  • Ability to load the model parameters via SDF.

I'll include a second part with the ray tracing to detect line of sight between the vehicles.

We don't have any tests yet, so to check it you have to play with the model parameters and the console/log output.

values.description:
It extends the communication model by checking if there's line of sight between the vehicles.

* If there's no line of sight caused by terrain, there's no communication.
* If the occlusion is caused by at least one wall, the wall penalty is applied. We don't know if there are other obstacles or more walls between the vehicles. However, the penalty for crossing a wall should be high enough that it doesn't matter what obstacles are after the wall, no communication either.
* If the occlusion is caused by at least one tree, the tree penalty is applied. I'm not 100% sure how the vegetation patches are going to work. Maybe we'll have to tweak this in the future because we cannot distinguish between crossing one or two tree lines.

This pull request requires pull request #16. [This is a better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/comms_model_part2%0Dadd_comms_model_caguero#diff) of the code added in part 2.
values.title: Communication model - part2

summary.raw:
It extends the communication model by checking if there's line of sight between the vehicles.

* If there's no line of sight caused by terrain, there's no communication.
* If the occlusion is caused by at least one wall, the wall penalty is applied. We don't know if there are other obstacles or more walls between the vehicles. However, the penalty for crossing a wall should be high enough that it doesn't matter what obstacles are after the wall, no communication either.
* If the occlusion is caused by at least one tree, the tree penalty is applied. I'm not 100% sure how the vegetation patches are going to work. Maybe we'll have to tweak this in the future because we cannot distinguish between crossing one or two tree lines.

This pull request requires pull request #16. [This is a better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/comms_model_part2%0Dadd_comms_model_caguero#diff) of the code added in part 2.
summary.html:
It extends the communication model by checking if there's line of sight between the vehicles.

  • If there's no line of sight caused by terrain, there's no communication.
  • If the occlusion is caused by at least one wall, the wall penalty is applied. We don't know if there are other obstacles or more walls between the vehicles. However, the penalty for crossing a wall should be high enough that it doesn't matter what obstacles are after the wall, no communication either.
  • If the occlusion is caused by at least one tree, the tree penalty is applied. I'm not 100% sure how the vegetation patches are going to work. Maybe we'll have to tweak this in the future because we cannot distinguish between crossing one or two tree lines.

This pull request requires pull request #16. This is a better diff of the code added in part 2.

values.reason: I'll rewrite some parts to make sure we capture all the use cases that we have discussed.

values.description:
It extends the communication model by checking if there's line of sight between the vehicles.

* If there's no line of sight caused by terrain, there's no communication.
* If the occlusion is caused by more than one obstacle we drop the package.
* If the occlusion is caused by one wall we drop the package. 
* If the occlusion is caused by one tree, the tree penalty is applied. 

This pull request requires pull request #16. [This is a better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/comms_model_part2%0Dadd_comms_model_caguero#diff) of the code added in part 2.
values.title: Communication model - part2

summary.raw:
It extends the communication model by checking if there's line of sight between the vehicles.

* If there's no line of sight caused by terrain, there's no communication.
* If the occlusion is caused by more than one obstacle we drop the package.
* If the occlusion is caused by one wall we drop the package. 
* If the occlusion is caused by one tree, the tree penalty is applied. 

This pull request requires pull request #16. [This is a better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/comms_model_part2%0Dadd_comms_model_caguero#diff) of the code added in part 2.
summary.html:
It extends the communication model by checking if there's line of sight between the vehicles.

  • If there's no line of sight caused by terrain, there's no communication.
  • If the occlusion is caused by more than one obstacle we drop the package.
  • If the occlusion is caused by one wall we drop the package.
  • If the occlusion is caused by one tree, the tree penalty is applied.

This pull request requires pull request #16. This is a better diff of the code added in part 2.

values.description:
This pull request creates the base of operations (BOO).

The BOO is derived from RobotPlugin, so it inherits all the communication capabilities. The BOO should use `<address>boo</address>` in all the world files. Any robot can send a message to the BOO using the target address `kBoo` and the destination port `kBooPort`. 

The BOO supports commands with syntax: `<CMD> [args]`. Right now, only the `FOUND` command is supported with the following syntax:

```
#!python

FOUND <x> <y> <z> <t> : Person found in [x,y,z] at time t, where:

x: X coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
y: Y coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
z: Z coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
t: Time at which the person was spotted (double).
```
E.g.: FOUND 100.0 50.0 1.0 10.4

The BOO keeps track of the history of the lost person's positions along time. The world has been discretized and the BOO stores the coordinates of the cells that the lost person is traversing and the time that entered that cell for the first time. The buffer only stores changes in the cells.

Additionally, the robots are only allowed to communicate FOUND commands with times no older than the current time - `kMaxDt`. The buffer of positions also uses this constant to recycle elements when possible.

When a FOUND message is dispatched, the reported position is converted to a 3D cell. We consider success when this cell matches the cell stored in the buffer. After success, a message is published on topic /swarm/found with the address of the robot that found the person, time, and its position. Also, the simulation is paused.
values.title: Boo

summary.raw:
This pull request creates the base of operations (BOO).

The BOO is derived from RobotPlugin, so it inherits all the communication capabilities. The BOO should use `<address>boo</address>` in all the world files. Any robot can send a message to the BOO using the target address `kBoo` and the destination port `kBooPort`. 

The BOO supports commands with syntax: `<CMD> [args]`. Right now, only the `FOUND` command is supported with the following syntax:

```
#!python

FOUND <x> <y> <z> <t> : Person found in [x,y,z] at time t, where:

x: X coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
y: Y coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
z: Z coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
t: Time at which the person was spotted (double).
```
E.g.: FOUND 100.0 50.0 1.0 10.4

The BOO keeps track of the history of the lost person's positions along time. The world has been discretized and the BOO stores the coordinates of the cells that the lost person is traversing and the time that entered that cell for the first time. The buffer only stores changes in the cells.

Additionally, the robots are only allowed to communicate FOUND commands with times no older than the current time - `kMaxDt`. The buffer of positions also uses this constant to recycle elements when possible.

When a FOUND message is dispatched, the reported position is converted to a 3D cell. We consider success when this cell matches the cell stored in the buffer. After success, a message is published on topic /swarm/found with the address of the robot that found the person, time, and its position. Also, the simulation is paused.
summary.html:
This pull request creates the base of operations (BOO).

The BOO is derived from RobotPlugin, so it inherits all the communication capabilities. The BOO should use <address>boo</address> in all the world files. Any robot can send a message to the BOO using the target address kBoo and the destination port kBooPort.

The BOO supports commands with syntax: <CMD> [args]. Right now, only the FOUND command is supported with the following syntax:

FOUND <x> <y> <z> <t> : Person found in [x,y,z] at time t, where:

x: X coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
y: Y coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
z: Z coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
t: Time at which the person was spotted (double).

E.g.: FOUND 100.0 50.0 1.0 10.4

The BOO keeps track of the history of the lost person's positions along time. The world has been discretized and the BOO stores the coordinates of the cells that the lost person is traversing and the time that entered that cell for the first time. The buffer only stores changes in the cells.

Additionally, the robots are only allowed to communicate FOUND commands with times no older than the current time - kMaxDt. The buffer of positions also uses this constant to recycle elements when possible.

When a FOUND message is dispatched, the reported position is converted to a 3D cell. We consider success when this cell matches the cell stored in the buffer. After success, a message is published on topic /swarm/found with the address of the robot that found the person, time, and its position. Also, the simulation is paused.

values.description:
Add a minimal naive controller that will random-walk ground and rotorcraft robots, yell when they see the lost person, and use a dumb relay-everything strategy to get the answer back to the BOO.

This strategy wins about half the time when used with `ground_easy_4.world`.

We could either merge this into the `boo` branch (it's a decent example of exercising that functionality), or wait until `boo` is merged, then retarget this PR to `default`.
values.title: Tutorial_7

summary.raw:
Add a minimal naive controller that will random-walk ground and rotorcraft robots, yell when they see the lost person, and use a dumb relay-everything strategy to get the answer back to the BOO.

This strategy wins about half the time when used with `ground_easy_4.world`.

We could either merge this into the `boo` branch (it's a decent example of exercising that functionality), or wait until `boo` is merged, then retarget this PR to `default`.
summary.html:
Add a minimal naive controller that will random-walk ground and rotorcraft robots, yell when they see the lost person, and use a dumb relay-everything strategy to get the answer back to the BOO.

This strategy wins about half the time when used with ground_easy_4.world.

We could either merge this into the boo branch (it's a decent example of exercising that functionality), or wait until boo is merged, then retarget this PR to default.

values.title: Add destination address/port to the comms user callback.

summary.html:
As requested in issue #6, this pull request adds the destination address and the destination port to the callback executed when the user's code receives a new message.

Before:

void OnDataReceived(const std::string &_srcAddress,                              
                    const std::string &_data);

After:

void OnDataReceived(const std::string &_srcAddress,
                    const std::string &_dstAddress,
                    const uint32_t _dstPort,
                    const std::string &_data);

values.description:
As far as I know we're not introducing noise in the commands that the teams send for moving the robots.

In `SetAngularVelocity()` (and in the case of a fixed wing), we were using the observed linear velocity to compute the new angular velocity to be applied to the robot. The observed linear velocity has noise, hence we were applying some noise to `SetAngularVelocity()`.

This pull request eliminates the potential noise from `SetAngularVelocty()`.
values.title: Remove potential noise from SetAngularVelocity()

summary.raw:
As far as I know we're not introducing noise in the commands that the teams send for moving the robots.

In `SetAngularVelocity()` (and in the case of a fixed wing), we were using the observed linear velocity to compute the new angular velocity to be applied to the robot. The observed linear velocity has noise, hence we were applying some noise to `SetAngularVelocity()`.

This pull request eliminates the potential noise from `SetAngularVelocty()`.
summary.html:
As far as I know we're not introducing noise in the commands that the teams send for moving the robots.

In SetAngularVelocity() (and in the case of a fixed wing), we were using the observed linear velocity to compute the new angular velocity to be applied to the robot. The observed linear velocity has noise, hence we were applying some noise to SetAngularVelocity().

This pull request eliminates the potential noise from SetAngularVelocty().

values.description:
At the beginning of `Loop()` we cache all the sensor measurements and the cached values are the ones returned to the user when requested.

We also cache the target velocities and only apply the new velocities at the end of each cycle.
values.title: Update sensors and apply velocities once per cycle

summary.raw:
At the beginning of `Loop()` we cache all the sensor measurements and the cached values are the ones returned to the user when requested.

We also cache the target velocities and only apply the new velocities at the end of each cycle.
summary.html:
At the beginning of Loop() we cache all the sensor measurements and the cached values are the ones returned to the user when requested.

We also cache the target velocities and only apply the new velocities at the end of each cycle.

values.description:
Last Ignition-transport pull request allows different library versions installed side by side. One of the side effects is that we need to specify the major library version in find_package.

Also, I tweaked the `swarm-config.cmake` file to export all the information about the internal Swarm dependencies. A client using our library shouldn't have to worry about gazebo, protobuf, ign-transport, zeromq, etc.
values.title: Update dependency information

summary.raw:
Last Ignition-transport pull request allows different library versions installed side by side. One of the side effects is that we need to specify the major library version in find_package.

Also, I tweaked the `swarm-config.cmake` file to export all the information about the internal Swarm dependencies. A client using our library shouldn't have to worry about gazebo, protobuf, ign-transport, zeromq, etc.
summary.html:
Last Ignition-transport pull request allows different library versions installed side by side. One of the side effects is that we need to specify the major library version in find_package.

Also, I tweaked the swarm-config.cmake file to export all the information about the internal Swarm dependencies. A client using our library shouldn't have to worry about gazebo, protobuf, ign-transport, zeromq, etc.

values.description:
Partial support for logging:

* When logging is enabled, a log file is automatically created under` ~/.swarm/log/<timestamp>/swarm.log`
* To enable the log file you should set the environment variable `SWARM_LOG` to `1`.
* The log contains all the sensor measurements and the actions sent to the robot (no comms yet).
* A `LogParser.hh` is provided to parse a log file.
* As an example of using `LogParser.hh`, I've created a basic `swarmlog` tool that introspects a log file. It has the same format as `gz log`.

Example of usage: 

* Compile and install as usual.
* Start `gzserver`:

```
#!python

SWARM_LOG=1 gzserver worlds/ground_simple_2.world
```

* Stop `gzserver` and inspect the log file:

```
#!python

swarmlog -s -f <YOUR_LOG_FILE>
```

I didn't focus on optimizing the logging for now. When we have everything working we can improve the logging performance if this is the bottleneck.

~~*Note: this PR is built atop pull request #35, which should be merged first.*~~
values.title: Logging - part 1

* When logging is enabled, a log file is automatically created under` ~/.swarm/log/<timestamp>/swarm.log`

summary.html:
Partial support for logging:

  • When logging is enabled, a log file is automatically created under~/.swarm/log/<timestamp>/swarm.log
  • To enable the log file you should set the environment variable SWARM_LOG to 1.
  • The log contains all the sensor measurements and the actions sent to the robot (no comms yet).
  • A LogParser.hh is provided to parse a log file.
  • As an example of using LogParser.hh, I've created a basic swarmlog tool that introspects a log file. It has the same format as gz log.

Example of usage:

  • Compile and install as usual.
  • Start gzserver:
SWARM_LOG=1 gzserver worlds/ground_simple_2.world
  • Stop gzserver and inspect the log file:
swarmlog -s -f <YOUR_LOG_FILE>

I didn't focus on optimizing the logging for now. When we have everything working we can improve the logging performance if this is the bottleneck.

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #35, which should be merged first.

values.description:
Three types of noise:

1. False negative: Some percentage of the time, do not include the detection of an object.
2. False positive: Some part of the time (based on distance), report seeing the lost person when the object is really another vehicle
3. Gaussian position noise, based on distance.
values.title: Adding noise to the logical camera.

values.description:
Adds the communication information to the log file. In each simulation cycle,

The broker plugin adds to the log:

* A visibility map: `NxN` matrix, where `N` is the number of robots in the swarm. In each element of the matrix we store the visibility status during this simulation cycle (`VISIBLE`, `OUTAGE`, `OBSTACLE` or `DISTANCE`). Note that `VISIBLE` doesn't mean that a potential message between the pair of robots will be delivered, just means that there's visibility between the two robots. The message might be discarded because of the message drop probability. 

* All the incoming messages: A collection of messages with source address, destination address, destination port and payload size. If the destination is `broadcast` we only save in the log one single message with `destination address = broadcast`. `multicast` behaves in a similar way.

In a nutshell, the broker logs a connectivity snapshot, as well as the list of all messages sent by robots.

Each robot plugin adds to the log:

* The list of messages received. For each message, the following fields are logged: source address, original destination address (broadcast, multicast, or a specific address for unicast), destination port, size, and whether the message will be delivered or not. At this point the only reason for not delivering the message should be because we have decided to drop the message.

Follow the same instructions described in pull request #37 for testing.

*Note: this PR is built atop pull request #37, which should be merged first. Here is a better [diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/logging_part2%0Dlogging_part1#diff)*.
values.title: Logging - part2

Adds the communication information to the log file. In each simulation cycle,

The broker plugin adds to the log:

* A visibility map: `NxN` matrix, where `N` is the number of robots in the swarm. In each element of the matrix we store the visibility status during this simulation cycle (`VISIBLE`, `OUTAGE`, `OBSTACLE` or `DISTANCE`). Note that `VISIBLE` doesn't mean that a potential message between the pair of robots will be delivered, just means that there's visibility between the two robots. The message might be discarded because of the message drop probability. 

* All the incoming messages: A collection of messages with source address, destination address, destination port and payload size. If the destination is `broadcast` we only save in the log one single message with `destination address = broadcast`. `multicast` behaves in a similar way.

In a nutshell, the broker logs a connectivity snapshot, as well as the list of all messages sent by robots.

Each robot plugin adds to the log:

* The list of messages received. For each message, the following fields are logged: source address, original destination address (broadcast, multicast, or a specific address for unicast), destination port, size, and whether the message will be delivered or not. At this point the only reason for not delivering the message should be because we have decided to drop the message.

Follow the same instructions described in pull request #37 for testing.

summary.html:
Adds the communication information to the log file. In each simulation cycle,

The broker plugin adds to the log:

  • A visibility map: NxN matrix, where N is the number of robots in the swarm. In each element of the matrix we store the visibility status during this simulation cycle (VISIBLE, OUTAGE, OBSTACLE or DISTANCE). Note that VISIBLE doesn't mean that a potential message between the pair of robots will be delivered, just means that there's visibility between the two robots. The message might be discarded because of the message drop probability.

  • All the incoming messages: A collection of messages with source address, destination address, destination port and payload size. If the destination is broadcast we only save in the log one single message with destination address = broadcast. multicast behaves in a similar way.

In a nutshell, the broker logs a connectivity snapshot, as well as the list of all messages sent by robots.

Each robot plugin adds to the log:

  • The list of messages received. For each message, the following fields are logged: source address, original destination address (broadcast, multicast, or a specific address for unicast), destination port, size, and whether the message will be delivered or not. At this point the only reason for not delivering the message should be because we have decided to drop the message.

Follow the same instructions described in pull request #37 for testing.

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #37, which should be merged first. Here is a better diff.

values.description:
Three types of noise:

1. False negative: Some percentage of the time (based on distance), do not include the detection of an object.
2. False positive: Some part of the time (based on distance), report seeing an incorrect object.
3. Position noise, based on distance.
values.title: Logical noise

summary.raw:

2. False positive: Some part of the time (based on distance), report seeing an incorrect object.
3. Position noise, based on distance.

values.description:
Implementation of a custom broker service that improves performance:

* Each robot registers as a broker client.
* The messages are stored in the broker (singleton).
* The broker interface exposes `Bind()` and `Push()` for sending messages.
* The broker plugin can read all the messages from the broker and check the clients bound to each endpoint. The broker client directly calls the callback for each broker client that should receive the messages.
* The RobotPlugin no longer logs communication information. All the comms are logged by the BrokerPlugin, that now has access to which clients are bound to each endpoint (including multicast).

Simulation is running at real-time in my laptop when loading `simple_ground_36.world` with the logging enabled.
values.title: Improve performance

summary.raw:
Implementation of a custom broker service that improves performance:

* Each robot registers as a broker client.
* The messages are stored in the broker (singleton).
* The broker interface exposes `Bind()` and `Push()` for sending messages.
* The broker plugin can read all the messages from the broker and check the clients bound to each endpoint. The broker client directly calls the callback for each broker client that should receive the messages.
* The RobotPlugin no longer logs communication information. All the comms are logged by the BrokerPlugin, that now has access to which clients are bound to each endpoint (including multicast).

Simulation is running at real-time in my laptop when loading `simple_ground_36.world` with the logging enabled.
summary.html:
Implementation of a custom broker service that improves performance:

  • Each robot registers as a broker client.
  • The messages are stored in the broker (singleton).
  • The broker interface exposes Bind() and Push() for sending messages.
  • The broker plugin can read all the messages from the broker and check the clients bound to each endpoint. The broker client directly calls the callback for each broker client that should receive the messages.
  • The RobotPlugin no longer logs communication information. All the comms are logged by the BrokerPlugin, that now has access to which clients are bound to each endpoint (including multicast).

Simulation is running at real-time in my laptop when loading simple_ground_36.world with the logging enabled.
